Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Carroll University Biological Field Station Improvement Project
Award.AbstractNarration:
Carroll University has received funds to create a research and education center at the Carroll University Greene Field Station (GFS). Despite the lack of on-site facilities for research and appropriate infrastructure to support data acquisition, management, and dissemination, Carroll faculty and students have conducted research at the GFS outdoor laboratory since the 1970s. The renovation of an existing building into a research facility will expand research agendas, provide infrastructure needed for outside collaboration and community use, and offer space for the university to introduce the experimenting across the curriculum initiative, a groundbreaking project that will integrate research and education, educating all students in scientific literacy. The research and education center will also provide the foundation needed for Carroll faculty to conduct ongoing projects both in ecological and pedagogical research.

The expanded GFS will serve as an important research facility not just for science students and faculty at Carroll University, but also for non-science majors to become citizen scientists. The observational and experimental data accessible at the facility will contribute to public participation in scientific research efforts and provide benefits to society. All Carroll students will be trained in the processes of sciences as they submit data collected at the GFS to regional and national databases. One quarter of Carroll's undergraduate students are first generation and 21% come from economically disadvantaged families. Providing an opportunity for students to participate in well-supported inquiry based learning at the facility through their general education coursework will broaden participation of underrepresented groups in the processes of science. The new facility will also broaden collaborations across universities, area school districts, non-profit agencies, and governmental agencies, thus enhancing the infrastructure for research and education in the community. More information about the GFS can be found at: http://www.carrollu.edu/greene-field-station/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the renovation of an existing 1,140 square foot barn at Carroll University's Greene Field Station (GFS) into an open classroom area and adjoining laboratory. Located in the Town of Genesse in Waukesha County, approximately 10 miles from the Carroll University campus, the GFS consists of two tracts of land totaling 60 acres. The GFS mission is "To serve as an outdoor laboratory for research and education by the faculty, students, and friends of Carroll University. In addtion, the GFS exists to protect ecologically significant natural areas in southeastern Wisconsin and promote research and education throughout the region with a primary focus on wetland and stream ecology." While the university has owned the field station land since 1969, it lacked the existence of a physical field station structure due to deed-based restrictions. In June, 2012, the university purchased an additional piece of property located south of and adjacent to the southern portion of the GFS. This property consists of 2.7 acres of wooded property with a 1,140 square foot barn. Carroll gained approval from the Town of Genesee, Waukesha County, and the State of Wisconsin to rezone the property from A-2 Rural Home District to P-1 Public and Instituitonal District status, Town of Genesse, Waukesha County Planning Commission, and building permits for all trades were obtained in Octobe 2015. Constrcution of the open classroom area and laboratory began November 2, 2016. Occupancy of the facility was awarded to the university on September 9, 2016.  The facility dedication was September 22. 2016. The university renovated the property to provide the infrastructure necessary so that the property now serves as a university resource for ecological education, research, and conservation.

The renovated open classroom area, equipped with a projection system, computers, and tables for interactive activities, supports inquiry-based environmental science learning for groups of up to 36 learners. The laboratory adjacent to the open classroom area allows for more sensitive research equipment to be connected to or separated from the open classroom area as needed. Infrastructure improvements to the classroom and laboratory included upgrades to the electrical system to accommodate equipment and technology needs, improved lighting and plumbing, replacement of non-functioning windows, and a new HVAC system.  Interior renovations to the classroom and laboratory included insulation, drywall, flooring, and finishing.  All infrastructure and interior improvements were planned with the intent to optimize energy efficiency. To meet technology needs, network infrastructure additions were made. Interactive display systems, computers, and security cameras were connected.  Exterior improvements to the barn facility included siding, roof repairs, and painting.
